title: shepherd
comment: The work of a shepherd was important and responsible in the rural world of ancient Palestine. Since it involved leading, protecting and feeding a flock, it is seen as a metaphor for the task of leadership. Scripture declares that God is the Shepherd of his people.

children.title: shepherd, as occupation
children.comment: The occupation of a shepherd was both humble and honourable. In the marginal hill country of Palestine it was particularly demanding.

children.title: A shepherd as a keeper of flocks of animals

secondaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew word refers to a keeper of goats and cattle as well as sheep.

seealsos.comment: The rod is a crook (for extracting sheep from difficulty) and the staff a club (for warding off wild animals)

children.title: The use of pens and folds
Rearing
children.precomment: Rebekah's ruse depended on a method used to get a ewe to accept an alien lamb:

secondaryrefs.comment: A shepherd who lost an animal to wild beasts had to produce evidence

children.title: shepherd, as king and leader
children.comment: Shepherd was a standard term for a leader or king throughout the ancient world. In this sense it often appears in the Bible.

children.title: General term for a king or leader

primaryrefs.comment: The prophet describes this non-Jewish king as God's shepherd

children.title: David as the model of a good shepherd

seealsos.comment: The king is brought to his senses by a ``shepherd'' story

children.title: The shepherd faces death for his flock
David as a model of the coming Messiah
A good shepherd as a leader ``after God's own heart''
Criticisms of the shepherds of Israel
shepherd, as church leader
children.comment: Church leaders are likened to shepherds, on account of their pastoral responsibilities and tasks.
